title: How did Nikola Tesla recreate ball lightning? - Quora

response.answer_text: Ah, you’d be wanting Corum & Corum “Fireball production from a Tesla Coil,” 2003, where James and Kenneth Corum set up a pair of overtone-tuned secondary coils with a common primary driver. This essentially produces a sort of “capacitive discharge” if ever the two plasma-streamers from the tops of the separate coils should touch together. The plasma shorts out the two secondaries, also instantly switching both to a single phase and a common lower frequency.  Tesla wrote that his “fireballs” were accidentally produced when strong overtones were present in his secondary coils, no doubt superposed in phase with the main oscillation sinewave. The higher harmonics cause the output waveform to have much sharper edges than pure sine waves, such as the 1,2,3, etc., harmonics of a delta function. With the Corum’s setup we’d expect a much larger, briefer discharge than the usual results seen when a lengthening plasma-streamer touches ground. Two streamer-tips merging, while momentarily charged to opposite high voltage, should give 2X the peak volts, and 4X the peak power, all occurring an an extremely sharp transition: over less than about a quarter-cycle of the higher frequency. Tesla called these “discharge of inconceivable violence,” (presumably where a slow-crawling spark from your Tesla coil, rather than buzzing as usual, suddenly goes “BANG!”) The Corums discovered that a pure metal electrode wouldn’t make any fireballs. Instead, various sources of contamination were required, including Nikola Tesla’s original gutta-percha or rubber wire-insulation, partially charred, or even set aflame by the plasma. The Corums found that the “BL” would only persist for a second or two. However, the strong e-field surrounding a Tesla coil would keep the BL going for much longer. (We also see something similar inside Microwave Ovens, where the HV field inside the oven can power a plasma for many minutes.) There is a legend that Tesla kept a bright red Ball Lightning in a little box, and carried it around with him. If true, what was the power supply? He’d need a portable Tesla coil, heavy batteries, etc. (Or, he’d just have to be inside his own lab, with wireless light bulbs everywhere, and the ceiling covered with metal plates connected to Tesla coil HV terminals.) Heh. On the other hand, maybe it wasn’t a BL, maybe it was just a wireless lightbulb: a device equally as magical as BL, back in 1905.  Apparently the “ball lightning” being produced in the Corums’ setup is the same thing as “weld spatter.” So-called weld-spatter is not simply some hot glowing metal droplets. Instead it is a weird, expanded structure, a fractal network of metal nanofilaments and incandescent gas. It’s not plasma, it’s actually fairly weighty, and tends to fall downwards and bounce around. (As it cools from its incandescent state, this “ball lightning” shrinks enormously, finally forming a warm metal bead or grain.) Below: modern “BL” produced by cap-discharge through a silicon wafer  . Besides the Corums …Robert Golka tried some Ball Lightning experiments with a huge tesla coil inside an aircraft hanger. Golka hoped that “ball lightning” might be an electrodynamic plasma-soliton; a stable structure which might provide the secret of non-turbulent plasma for nuclear fusion reactors. But the Corums (as well as earlier Russian research with capacitor-discharge) found that “BL” instead more resembles a white-hot chunk of aerogel, where the initial air/plasma combination condenses into a “gel nanostructure,” a three-dimensional fractal percolation structure having a very low density. Like metal feathers, or metal styrofoam, heated white hot. Below, R. Golka, shorting out his submarine battery (YT vid)

Ball Lightning is a strange and rare occurance, with thousands of anecdotal witnesses. Basically it appears as a luminous ball that floats through the air, often during lightning storms. They seem to contain a large amount of stored energy, which is occasionally unleashed on objects they contact. Some people think it is just swamp gas and a lot of imagination. Maxwell’s Equations (as reduced by Oliver Heavyside) do not admitt the existance of this phenomenon, and yet there are too many accounts to regard this asmere folklore. Tesla claimed to be able to create clusters of such balls at will with his equipment. To my knowledge, no one knows how he did it. I read an account of someone claiming to create ball lightning in a microwave oven. He said he lit a candle in the oven and then microwaved it. He thought the carbon plasma from the candle somehow nucleated the effect. I have not tried this…
